comments.author: Anthony Tran

comments.text:
Brining doesn't alter the cooking, it just makes the meat more tender & 
juicy. Cook it at the same time and temp as you would normally.

Most meat you should refresh after brining, you do this by soaking it in a 
bucket of cold (unsalted water) water for an hour, change this water at 
least every 15 minutes, otherwise your meat will taste overly salty.

As an alternative, look up "equilibrium brining", it's much easier, uses 
less salt, doesn't need refreshing but does need more time.
comments.author: thedr00

top_comment.author: drobecxxx

comments.text:
+ZoruaDZN if u are using tomatoes or dry wine or vinegar it's OK but 
otherwise it's not necessary to use sugar, for example dry rubs, meat is 
sweat enough and has enough flavor on its own, sugar is not necessary there 
are many other better spices but what ever
comments.author: drobecxxx

comments.text:
Sugar caramelises giving off a sweet, rich taste, most of the time it's 
counteracted with things like lemon, lime, vinegar, for a great balance of 
flavour. Sugar brings out more flavour in things like fresh tomato sauces 
purely due to the balancing.

comments.author: ManyAwesome

comments.text:
There is such a thing as *over*-brining. I let one brine for 48 hours one 
year, and it was so sopping wet after cooking that I wanted to wring it out 
before carving (DJ's turkey looks overbrined to me). I think an hour per 
pound is about right, so no more than 24 hours for a 20-24 lb turkey should 
be about perfect. I use a solution of 1 cup kosher salt per gallon of 
water, plus whatever herbs I feel like (rosemary, cracked tellicherry 
pepper, lemon juice and zest).
comments.author: Gary Royal

top_comment.author: ebbtides

comments.text:
+MusingsofaJay put some veg in a tray with a splash of water. You can put 
bacon atop the turkey if you want. , go with about 150degrees celcius for 
2-3hrs covered (foil), then you can take it out, turn heat to 220degrees 
and cook uncovered for about half an hour. Rest for about as long as you 
cooked, but an hour should be sufficient if you're in a hurry. Use pan 
drippings and veg to make some kind of gravy.
